front-end.name: Portfolio Website
front-end.description: First project. A daunting task, having only just completed tutorials on front-end technologies. This project was a slow-burner, adding new sections as projects were completed and technologies were learned. The portfolio was then adapted and reconstructed in Node.js and Express.js, using the EJS view engine The current portfolio resides has been deployed to Heroku.

front-end.name: Random Quote Generator
front-end.description: Second project built as part of FCC curriculum. A fun little project which used an array of quotes and a random number generator to select one. One interesting aspect of this project adapting the quotes to fit with Twitter's 140 character maximum. This mean that longer quotes had to be shortened with sufficient space to allow author attribution.

front-end.name: Pomodoro Clock
front-end.description: This was the first project that felt like a true challenge. How does one go about implementing a timer function? In the end, settled on using the JavaScript Date function to benchmark a second, and this accurate second was passed in to the SetInterval function to implement a countdown.

front-end.name: Calculator
front-end.description: Another tough project. The arithmetic functions were easy to define, but the challenge was in storing and reading the order in which keys were pressed and subsequently performing the operation. Potential to refactor this project in a more Functional Programming manner using currying.

front-end.name: Local Weather
front-end.description: First single app app to be built using a call to an API. There were two aspects to this project - being able to access a user's gelocation data, and translating this to an API call to a weather API, allowing for the app to display the weather in the current location.

front-end.name: Twitch TV
front-end.description: Exploration into using APIs and Angular! This was a fun project which included a call to the TwitchTV API, and displaying the output using Angular.

front-end.name: Camper News
front-end.description: API-based project which called to the FCC News API. Another fun project which was more front-end focused. Extracting the data from the API is easy enough with the fun laying in the design elements of the UI.

front-end.name: Wikipedia Viewer
front-end.description: A slightly tougher API project. The Wikipedia API doesn't seem as simple to navigate as other APIs used so far, however, Wikipedia had a handy tool that allowed users to construct the URL for the API call. Angular was used to display the results to the screen with an AJAX call to implement the auto-complete function.

front-end.name: Tic Tac Toe
front-end.description: Toughest project to date. Initially begun with an education in AI - looking at the MiniMax algorith and alpha-beta pruning. Decided upon a hard-coded route, whereby the "AI's" decision was a result of the player's previous moves.

front-end.name: Simon Game
front-end.description: First project built in an object-oriented manner. Included by first attempts at test-driven development, with testing carried out using QUnit.

full-stack.name: Timestamp Microservice
full-stack.description: A resource that responds to a HTTP GET request which included a date string or unix stamp, and responsed with a JSON object showing both unix and datestamp properties. A particularly fun project which helped to in my understanding of how Node.js works.

full-stack.name: Request Header Parser Microservice
full-stack.description: A resource that responds to a HTTP GET request and responsed with a JSON object showing both the IP, language and operating-system of the user. This project used nothing but the request headers sent with the GET request to extract the relevant information.

full-stack.name: URL Shortener Microservice - awaiting deployment
full-stack.description: First full-stack project. A user submits a URL and is provided with a "short" URL! A more involved project that required documents to be stored to MongoDB - needed to check whether a URL had been entered before and if so, provide that unique short URL in response.
